terms.definition: Building from machine-readable specifications as the single source of truth. All project data (geometry, colors, hardware BOM, print settings) is defined in JSON and consumed by scripts, pipelines, and dashboards.
One authoritative data file (.state/spec.json) that drives all downstream outputs. Change a dimension or color here and every generated model, export, and dashboard page reflects it automatically.
Project metadata stored in structured JSON files (.state/*.json) consumed by dashboards and pipelines. Components, features, tasks, and changelog are all machine-readable and rendered in the browser.
Dimensions defined as variables so the entire model updates from parameter changes. The base, height, taper ratio, wall thickness, and tolerances are all spec parameters, not hardcoded values.
Automated build process that runs without a GUI. FreeCAD executes Python scripts via CLI to generate geometry, assign colors, and export STL/3MF files without ever opening a window.
Automated sequence: generate model from Python script, assign per-component colors from spec.json, export individual STLs and a single multi-color 3MF. Run with ./pipeline/build.sh.
Single 3MF file containing multiple bodies with per-body color assignment. Enables multi-material or multi-color printing from one file instead of separate STLs per color.
Triangle mesh format for 3D printing. The pipeline exports one STL per component (8 total) for single-color printing or individual part replacement.
Scripting interface for parametric CAD modeling. Part.makeLoft(), shape.cut(), and Part::Feature objects are used to create tapered geometry, boolean cuts, and assemblies entirely in code.
Running FreeCAD via CLI (FreeCAD -c) without opening the GUI. The Python script executes in console mode, generates all 8 objects, and the pipeline exports them with zero manual interaction.
Tool-free retention clips that flex to hold components. The SSD and Ethernet mounts use flexible plastic rails that deflect during insertion and spring back to lock the component in place.
Cylindrical pocket (6mm diameter, 1.5mm deep) for press-fitting neodymium magnets. 24 recesses total across the shell and 4 panels enable tool-free magnetic panel attachment.
Clearance gap (0.3mm) between mating parts for reliable fit. Applied between panels and shell openings so parts slide together without binding or excessive wobble.
Geometry created by blending a base wire to a smaller top wire using Part.makeLoft(). The 140x100mm base transitions to 119x85mm at the top, creating the tapered spire shape.
Internal fill pattern density for 3D printing. Structural parts like the shell use 15% infill for strength-to-weight ratio; solid panels use 100% for rigidity and surface quality.
Three.js browser-based 3D viewer with orbit controls, multiple viewports (front, right, top, isometric), and wireframe overlays. Loads STL meshes and colors directly from spec.json.
Components separated spatially to show assembly relationships. The spec viewer can spread parts apart along their mount axis so you can see how the shell, mounts, and panels nest together.
HTML pages that fetch and render directly from JSON state files. No build step and no framework required. Vanilla HTML/JS reads .state/*.json and renders components, features, tasks, and changelog.
UI control for isolating individual parts in the 3D viewer. Click a component name to show/hide it, making it easy to inspect geometry, check fit, or verify port cutout alignment.
A discrete printable part with its own STL, color assignment, and print settings. The project has 8 components: MainShell, 3 internal mounts, and 4 decorative panels.
A tracked capability with phase-based progress (planning, design, implementation, testing, completion). Features map to implementation plans and are tracked in .state/features.json.
Version-tagged record of all project changes stored in .state/changelog.json. Each version entry lists changes by type (feature, fix, refactor, docs) with component references.
Detailed spec document written before building a feature. Defines requirements, approach, affected components, and acceptance criteria. This applies the spec-driven methodology to project management.
